titleInfo.title: Cloud Feedbacks and Convective Self-Aggregation in the Radiative-Convective Equilibrium Model Intercomparison Project

name.namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.abstract: Changes in cloud properties in response to surface warming have been consistently identified as the feedback contributing the largest uncertainty in the overall climate feedback parameter, which describes changes in top of atmosphere radiation balance in response to warming surface temperatures. The primary concern regarding clouds are twofold: (i) Clouds have competing influences on the climate. Their high albedo reflects solar insolation, cooling the climate system while simultaneously absorbing and re-emitting the radiation emitted by the Earth, a warming effect on the climate system. (ii) Clouds are inherently a subgrid-scale process for most climate change studies (such as those using global climate models), necessitating the use of a parameterization scheme. Here, an ensemble of models of many types in an idealized configuration of the tropical climate is leveraged to investigate how and why deep-convecting clouds change the way they do, what the resultant cloud feedbacks are from these changes, and how organized convection affects these changes and cloud feedbacks. Deep-convecting anvils, independent of how cloud fraction is defined, increase in height, increase slightly in temperature, and (generally) decrease in cloud fraction with warming sea surface temperature while mid-level cloud fraction robustly decreases with warming. The response of tropical clouds to warming found in this work follows previously established physical reasoning, confirming this reasoning across a much larger ensemble of models that explicitly simulate convection than previously considered. The cloud feedbacks associated with these changes generally align with results using comprehensive global climate models and observations, especially for cloud feedbacks associated with tropical high clouds. However, when convection organizes, different cloud regimes become more important. There is an established understanding that organized convection alters the mean climate state. If convective organization is absent, the cloud feedbacks have a smaller magnitude. Amongst domains that have convective organization, if a domain is strongly organized, the cloud feedbacks are weaker and sometimes switch sign. This is primarily due to the impact of changes in cloud optical depth in the shortwave, specifically high clouds thickening (as opposed to thinning) with warming in strongly organized domains, as well as more strongly organized domains having more low clouds to begin with. The shortwave cloud optical depth feedback also plays an important role in causing the tropical anvil cloud area feedback to be positive which is directly opposed to the expected negative cloud feedback found in prior work. This calls into question the expectation for and assumptions regarding a negative tropical anvil cloud area feedback, particularly the role of changes in cloud optical depth with warming, especially given these simulations more accurately resolve convection.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
climate sensitivity, cloud feedbacks, idealized modeling, organized convection, radiative-convective equilibrium, tropical convection
Allison Wing, Professor Directing Dissertation; Eric Chicken, University Representative; Alyssa Atwood, Committee Member; Mark Bourassa, Committee Member; Guosheng Liu, Committee Member.
